(1896). Nihongi, pp. 109. == Traditional history == Ninken was a grandson of Emperor Richū; and he was adopted by the childless Emperor Seinei.Aston, William. (1998). Nihongi, Vol. 1, pp. 373-377. == Events of Ninken's life == Very little is known about the events of Ninken's life and reign. Only limited information is available for study prior to the reign of the 29th monarch, Emperor Kimmei.Titsingh, pp. 34-36; Brown, pp. 261-262; Varley, pp. 123-124. === After his death === This emperor's official name after his death (his posthumous name) was regularized many centuries after the lifetime which was ascribed to Ninken.Aston (1998), pp. 146-147. According to the Imperial Household Agency, the emperor's final resting place is in an earthen tumulus (kofun). Ninken is venerated at a memorial Shinto shrine (misasagi) which is associated with the burial mound. ==Related pages== * Emperor of Japan * List of emperors of Japan * Japanese imperial family tree * Kofun period == References == Category:Emperors of Japan
